case_name: Lala Ram Swaruup and others v. Shikar Chand and another

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 116 of 1964 arising from judgment dated September 13, 1960 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 212 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 116. of 1964. Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1960, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 212, of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 Lala Ram Swaruup and five other family members sued respondents Shikar Chand and his son for ejectment from shop in Qasba Chandausi, Bazar Waram.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant No. 1, Lala Ram Swaruup, and five other members of his family sued the two respondents, Shikar Chand and his son, for ejectment from the shop situated in Qasba Chandausi, Bazar Waram,

facts.text: Premises let out to respondents to conduct their shop on monthly rent with effect from April 11, 1952 for one year.

anchor.surface_text: on the allegation that the said premises had been let out to the respondents to companyduct their shop on a monthly rent with effect from the 11th April, 1952, for a year.

facts.text: U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947 was in force at the time the suit was brought.

anchor.surface_text: At the time when the present suit was brought, the U.P. Temporary  Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947  U.P. Act III of 1947   hereinafter called the Act  was in force.

facts.text: Appellants pleaded they needed the premises to carry on their own business.

anchor.surface_text: In their plaint, the appellants pleaded that they needed the premises in suit to carry on their own business in the shop,

facts.text: Appellants applied for permission to District Magistrate Moradabad under S.3(1), which was refused, then moved Commissioner under S.3(2) who granted permission.

anchor.surface_text: and they alleged that they had applied for permission-to the District Magistrate, Moradabad, under S. 3  1   of the Act that the said permission had been refused by him, whereupon they had moved the Commissioner in his revisions jurisdiction under S. 3  2  of the Act and that the Commissioner had given them permission to file the suit.

facts.text: Suit No. 349 of 1954 filed on July 14, 1954 claiming ejectment and damages for use and occupation from April 11, 1953 to July 11, 1954 at Rs. 35 per month.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants further claim- ed ejectment of the respondents and asked for a decree for damages. for use and occupation of the suit premises from 11th April, 1953 to 11th July, 1954 Rs. 35/- per month. The suit  No. 349, of 1954  was filed on the 14th July, 1954.

facts.text: Respondents resisted suit claiming non-joinder of parties, permission by Commissioner invalid, rent note inadmissible, notice under S.106 T.P. Act invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents resisted the claim made by the appelants on. several grounds. They urged that the suit was bad for number- joinder of necessary parties that the permission to sue granted to the appellants by the Commissioner was number valid in law that the rent numbere executed by them was number admissible in evidence and that the numberice given by the appellants under section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act was also invalid in law.

facts.text: Munsif Chandausi decreed suit in favour of appellants on March 25, 1955 with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge recorded findings in favour of the appellants on all the issues and decreed their suit with companyts on the 25th March, 1955.

facts.text: Respondents appealed to District Judge Moradabad in Civil Appeal No. 213 of 1955, dismissed on June 2, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents then preferred an appeal  Civil Appeal No. 213 of 1955  in the Court of the District Judge, Moradabad, and urged that the findings recorded by the trial Judge were erroneous and asked for the reversal of the decree passed by him. The learned District Judge rejected the respondents companytentions and companyfirmed the decree under appeal on the 2nd June, 1955.

facts.text: Second appeal No. 1106 of 1955 to Allahabad High Court, single judge held permission invalid, suit incompetent, judgment July 26, 1956, allowed leave for Letters Patent Appeal.

anchor.surface_text: That took the respondents to the High Court at Allahabad in second appeal  No. 1106 of 1955 . The learned single Judge of the said High Court who heard this appeal, upheld the respondents companytention that the permission granted by the Commissioner under s. 3  3  of the Act was invalid in law and so, he came to the companyclusion that the appellants suit was incompetent. This judgment was delivered on the 26th July, 1956. The learned Judge, however, allowed the appellants leave to file a Letters Patent Appeal.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal heard by larger bench of three judges, differed on validity of permission, majority held invalid, dismissed on September 13, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The Letters Patent Appeal was placed before a larger Bench of three learned Judges of the High Court, because it was thought that the question raised by the appellants was of some importance. On the question as to whether the permission granted by the Commissioner was valid or number, the learned Judges who heard the appeal differed. Two of the learned Judges held that the said permission was invalid, whilst the third learned Judge held that it was valid. In accordance with the majority opinion the Letters Patent appeal.preferred by the appellants was dismissed on the 13th September, 1960.

facts.text: Appellants obtained certificate from High Court and appealed to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then applied for and obtained a certificate from the High Court and it is with the said certificate that this appeal has companye to this Court.

facts.text: Ground of personal need for ejectment not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to cite the said grounds, because it is number disputed that the ground of personal need set out by the appellants justifies their claim for the respondents ejectment.

facts.text: District Magistrate refused permission, Commissioner granted it in revision.

anchor.surface_text: and they alleged that they had applied for permission-to the District Magistrate, Moradabad, under S. 3  1   of the Act that the said permission had been refused by him, whereupon they had moved the Commissioner in his revisions jurisdiction under S. 3  2  of the Act and that the Commissioner had given them permission to file the suit.

facts.text: Supreme Court held civil courts jurisdiction excluded except for pleas rendering order nullity.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that Mr. Goyal is right in companytending that the jurisdiction of the civil companyrts is excluded in relation to matters companyered by the orders included within the provisions of s. 3  4  and s. 16.

facts.text: Supreme Court held permission by Commissioner valid, not limited to jurisdictional errors.

anchor.surface_text: That is why it must be held that the High Court was in error in companying to the companyclu- sion that the permission granted by the Commissioner in exercise of the powers companyferred on him by s. 3 k 3  is invalid in law.

facts.text: Proceedings under S.3 are quasi-judicial, must follow natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: the view which was taken by this Court in that case was that the proceedings taken by a landlord under S. 3 are proceedings of a quasi-judicial nature and the appropriate authorities, in exercising their powers in relation to such proceedings, must act in accordance with the principles of natural justice.

facts.text: S.3(2) allows revision within 30 days from order or communication.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 2  and  3  as they stood at the relevant time read thus - The party aggrieved by the order of District Magistrate granting or refusing to grant the permission referred to in sub- section  1  may, within 30days from the date of the order or the date on which it is companymuni- 5 57 cated to him, whichever is later, apply to the Commissioner to revise the order.

facts.text: Commissioner's order final subject to State Government under S.7-F.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3  4  provides that the order of the Commissioner under sub- section  3  shall subject to any order passed by the State Government under s. 7-F, be final.

Section 3 of the Act imposes certain restrictions on the landlords right to eject his tenant from the premises to which the Act applies. Broadly stated, the effect of the provisions contained in S. 3 1  is that a landlord can evict his tenant if he satisfies two conditions.

issues.text: Whether the courts below had jurisdiction to consider the question about the validity of the permission granted by the Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of this appeal, the first point which Mr. Goyal for the appellants has raised for our decision is that the courts below had no jurisdiction to consider the question about the validity of the permission granted by the Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The second point which then calls for our decision in the present appeal is is the permission granted by the Commissioner without jurisdiction and as such, a nullity ?

arguments.claim: Permission by Commissioner valid; High Court erred in holding it invalid

anchor.surface_text: That is why it must be held that the High Court was in error in coming to the conclusion that the permission granted by the Commissioner in exercise of the powers conferred on him by s. 3  3  is invalid in law.

holdings.text: The jurisdiction of the civil courts is excluded in relation to matters covered by the orders included within the provisions of s. 3(4) and s. 16.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that Mr. Goyal is right in contending that the jurisdiction of the civil courts is excluded in relation to matters covered by the orders included within the provisions of s. 3 4  and s. 16.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 3(4) and 16 use clear and unambiguous words excluding jurisdiction; special statute provides adequate alternative remedy through State Government revision under s.7-F.

holdings.text: The bar created by the relevant provisions of the Act excluding the jurisdiction of the civil courts cannot operate in cases where the plea raised before the civil court goes to the root of the matter and would, if upheld, lead to the conclusion that the impugned order is a nullity.

anchor.surface_text: the bar created by the relevant provisions of the Act excluding the jurisdiction of the civil courts cannot operate in cases where the plea raised before the civil court goes to the root of the matter and would, if upheld, lead to the conclusion that the impugned order is a nullity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents like Mask & Co. and Kamala Mills hold that civil courts retain jurisdiction over nullities such as jurisdictional defects, non-compliance with mandatory procedures, or natural justice violations despite statutory bars.

holdings.text: The proceedings taken by a landlord under S. 3 are proceedings of a quasi-judicial nature and the appropriate authorities, in exercising their powers in relation to such proceedings, must act in accordance with the principles of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: the view which was taken by this Court in that case was that the proceedings taken by a landlord under S. 3 are proceedings of a quasi-judicial nature and the appropriate authorities, in exercising their powers in relation to such proceedings, must act in accordance with the principles of natural justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Supreme Court's prior decision in Lala Shri Bhagwan v. Shri Ram Chand confirming quasi-judicial nature of S.3 proceedings.

holdings.text: The jurisdiction conferred on the Commissioner under s. 3(3) is not exactly similar to the jurisdiction conferred on the High Court under s. 115 CPC; it is broader and not limited to jurisdictional errors.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the requirements of clauses a , b c all centre round the question about the jurisdiction of the subordinate court, and the view which has been accepted by the majority decision under appeal is that the same limitation must be imported in construing the scope of the authority and power conferred on the Commissioner by S. 3 3 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of S.3(3) unambiguous; empowers interference for illegality, material irregularity, or wrongful refusal to act without reference to jurisdiction; unlike CPC s.115 which centers on jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The permission granted by the Commissioner in exercise of the powers conferred on him by s. 3(3) is valid in law; the High Court erred in holding it invalid.

anchor.surface_text: That is why it must be held that the High Court was in error in coming to the conclusion that the permission granted by the Commissioner in exercise of the powers conferred on him by s. 3  3  is invalid in law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Commissioner's revisional powers under S.3(3) broad enough to grant permission after DM refusal; no jurisdictional limitation applies; thus not a nullity.

holdings.text: Only pleas that the impugned order is a nullity can be raised in civil court; all other pleas challenging correctness or propriety are barred by ss. 3(4) and 16.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already emphasised, the only plea which can be raised before a civil court in relation to orders passed under the relevant provisions of the Act can be a plea which, if sustained, would render the order wholly invalid and as such, a nullity. No other plea can be raised, because all other pleas are barred by ss. 3 4  and 16 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes merits review (barred) from nullity challenges (permitted); consistent with exclusion test and precedents.

precedents.citation: Secretary of State v. Mask Co. 1

anchor.surface_text: The same principle has been emphasised by the Privy Council in Secretary of State v. Mask Co. 1 . In that case, though the words used in sections 188 and 191 of the Sea Customs Act  1878  were held to exclude the jurisdiction of the civil companyrts, A.I.R. 1924 P.C. 175.  2  67 1. A. 222 the Privy Council observed that even where jurisdiction is excluded, the civil companyrts have jurisdiction to examine into cases where the provisions of the Act have number been companyplied -with, or the statutory tribunal has number acted in companyformity with the fundamental principles of judicial procedure.

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State v Mask & Co
precedents.cited_proposition: even where jurisdiction excluded by statute, civil courts can examine non-compliance with Act provisions or fundamental principles of judicial procedure including natural justice

Governor General in Council 3 . The companyclusion reached by this Court in M s. Kamala Mills case 1  also supports the view which we are taking in the present appeal.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already emphasised, the only plea which can be raised before a civil court in relation to orders passed under the relevant provisions of the Act can be a plea which, if sustained, would render the order wholly invalid and as such, a nullity. No other plea can be raised, because all other pleas are barred by ss. 3 4  and 16 of the Act.

That is why it must be held that the High Court was in error in coming to the conclusion that the permission granted by the Commissioner in exercise of the powers conferred on him by s. 3 3  is invalid in law.
